caption:
Table 1: Comparison with prior SOTA on image/video captioning and question answering (QA) tasks. *: 
evaluated on the public server. CIDEr scores are reported for Captioning tasks. Details of GIT2 are presented in 
supplementary materials.

Table 2: Results on image captioning. *: the nubmers are from [96]; CE: cross-entropy optimization. All 
numbers are CIDEr scores, and other metrics are shown in supplementary materials.

Table 3: Results on visual question answering. (a): for VQAv2, approaches are divided according to whether the 
answer vocabulary is pre-defined (Closed) or not (Open) during inference. The model with closed vocabulary 
can be a classification model or generation model with constrained outputs, e.g., [108, 61]. The two numbers in 
parenthesis are the number of parameters and the number of images (the images for pre-trained modules are not 
counted) in VL pretraining. (b): for TextVQA, Mia [87] # is the winner entry of TextVQA Challenge 2021 with 
a fine-tuned T5-3B [89] model. (c): ## : winner entry of 2021 VizWiz Grand Challenge Workshop.
Table 4: Results on video captioning. E : model ensemble; T : with the subtitle as additional input.

Table 7. The accuracy on individual test sets is in supplementary materials. Our TextCaps-fine-tuned 
captioning model achieves an 89.9 accuracy, which demonstrates the strong scene text comprehension 
capability of our captioning model. After fine-tuning the model on the standard MJ+ST datasets, GIT 
achieves 92.9 that surpasses the prior arts

Table 7: Results on scene text recognition. MJ and 
ST indicate the MJSynth (MJ) [45, 46] and Synth-
Text (ST) [33] datasets used for training scene text 
recognition models.

Table 8: Ablation study of larger text decoders. The models are pre-trained on a subset of 0.4B image-text pairs. 
No beam search and no SCST are performed.

Table 9: Model configurations in pre-training. The decoder is a 6-layer transformer network. The hidden size is 
768 with 12 attention heads except GIT2. Parameters of text token embeddings and the last projection weight 
before the softmax layer are shared and not counted in the model size.

Table 10: Results on COCO captioning with Karpathy [53] split. SimVLM: C4 (800GB) dataset are used and 
not included in the table; Flamingo: 27M video-text pairs are not counted in the table. UniversalCaptioner: the 
extra 0.3B in parameters is CLIP/ViT-L, which is used as feature and keyword extractor. the data for pre-training 
CLIP/ViT-L are not counted . VinVL/LEMON/OSCAR/MiniVLM/DistillVLM: the extra parameters are for 
object detector; data for the object detectors are not counted.

Table 11: Results on COCO test set evaluated on the public server. c5/c40: Each image is paired with 5 or 40 
reference ground-truth captions. B: BLEU [84]; M: METEOR [18]; R: ROUGE-L [68]; C: CIDEr-D [101].
Table 12: Results on nocaps. in.: in-domain; near.: near domain; out.: out-of-domain; C: CIDEr. S: SPICE.

Table 13: Results on TextCaps [96]. Test set is evaluated by the server. *: the numbers are from [96]. B: 
BLEU@4; M: METEOR; R: ROUGE-L; S: SPICE; C: CIDEr. # : winner entry of the CVPR 2021 workshop 
challenge 15 .

Table 14: Results on VizWiz-Captions. Both test-dev and test-std are evaluated on the server. # : winner entry of 
2021 VizWiz Grand Challenge 16 . B@4: BLEU@4; M: METEOR; R: ROUGE-L; C: CIDEr-D; S: SPICE.

Table 15: Results on visual question answering. (a): for VQAv2, approaches are divided according to whether 
the answer vocabulary is pre-defined (Closed) or not (Open) during inference. The model with closed vocabulary 
can be a classification model or generation model with constrained outputs, e.g., [108, 61]. (b): for TextVQA, 
Mia [87] # is the winner entry of TextVQA Challenge 2021 with a fine-tuned T5-3B [89] model. (c): ## : winner 
entry of 2021 VizWiz Grand Challenge Workshop.

Table 16: Results on video captioning. E : model ensemble; T : with the subtitle as additional input. YouCook2 
and TVC are on the validation set.

caption: Table 17: Results on video question answering. All are open-ended question answering tasks.

Table 18: Fine-tuning epochs and learning rate of GIT on video tasks. SCST [90] is performed for VATEX with 
the same hyperprameters.

caption:
Table 19: Results on ImageNet-1k classification task. Our approach takes the class name as the caption and 
predict the label in an auto-regressive way without pre-defining the vocabulary.

Table 20: Results on scene text recognition. MJ and ST indicate the MJSynth (MJ) [45, 46] and SynthText 
(ST) [33] datasets used for training scene text recognition models.

Table 21: Comparison between pure self-attention-based decoder and the cross-attention-based decoder under 
different amounts of pre-training data. No SCST is applied on captioning. No intermediate fine-tuning is applied 
for VQA.

caption:
Table 22: Effectiveness of the intermediate fine-tuning on VQA tasks. The gain is large when the target training 
data scale is small.
